awd_titl_txt: Dimension of  p  Harmonic Measure and Related Topics
awd_abstract_narration:
This  proposal is  concerned  with   the  dimension of a  measure associated with a positive  solution to the  p  Laplace equation, often called a  p harmonic function,  which  vanishes  continuously on the boundary of  a domain and related problems. If  p is two  the  p  Laplace equation reduces to  Laplace's equation and the Green's  function for Laplace's equation,  with pole at a fixed point in the domain, gives harmonic measure.  This measure  has had numerous  applications in   Potential  Theory and  applied areas throughout the twentieth century.  In the mid 1980's   mathematicians began to study the Hausdorff  dimension of  harmonic measure.    In an important paper,    Makarov   proved that harmonic measure in simply connected planar domains always has dimension one.  Jones and  Wolf  showed that the dimension of this measure is always  less than or equal to one in any planar domain.  The proposer has  obtained  endpoint type analogues of  Makarov's work  for  p  harmonic  measures, when p is between one  and  infinity.  In this proposal  he discusses possible techniques  for studying p harmonic measures in   arbitrary planar domains  and  also  in  certain  domains in  higher dimensional Euclidean space.


  Laplace's  equation  was  used widely throughout the nineteenth and twentieth centuries to explain physical processes. Its nonlinear cousin, the p Laplacian, has only  recently  found applications in mathematical modeling (glacier formation, image processing) perhaps  because this PDE  is difficult to work with.  The  PI's work with coauthors  gives the p Laplacian strong visibility in an  area  previously  reserved for the Laplacian.The PI and coauthors have  developed a  p harmonic toolbox which  enabled  them to make significant progress on problems previously considered solvable only  for Laplace's equation.     The PI believes that the techniques, results, and  problems discussed in his proposal  will   play an important role in popularizing the p Laplacian and  also  have applications in mathematical modeling. These  problems - techniques  involve a nice mixture of  harmonic analysis,  complex function theory, and partial differential equations, so should be attractive to researchers and  graduate students in  a  wide  area of  mathematical and  applied analysis.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
My research during this research period was on nonlinear partial differential equations (PDE's) , modeled on the p Laplace equation. Here p is fixed, and greater than 1. The p Laplace equation reduces to Laplace's equation when p = 2. Throughout my career I have tried to generalize well known theorems for Laplace's equation to the p Laplace equation. Often I have failed as the p Laplacian, when p is not equal to 2, is nonlinear and degenerate elliptic. Thus the sum of two solutions need not be a solution and a solution loses ellipticity whenever its gradient vanishes. As a consequence tools used for linear PDE, such as representation formulas, fourier series and transforms, harmonic measure, are not available. when p is not equal to 2. During this grant coauthors and myself studied the `dimension of p harmonic measure.' To give a little history, harmonic measure was developed in the early twentieth century to study the Dirichlet problem for solutions to Laplace's equation (called harmonic functions). Over the years, harmonic measure has had important use as a bridge in describing connections between rather diverse topics, such as Brownian motion and Newtonian capacity. One question popularized by famous mathematicians during my early mathematical career was `to determine the dimension or size of harmonic measure in a planar domain'. This question was finally answered in 1985 by Makorov who showed that the dimension of harmonic measure is always less than or equal to 1 for domains without holes (called simply connected domains). Jones and Wolff later generalized this result to all planar domains and Wolff showed that the natural conjecture for harmonic measure (based on the planar case) is false in three dimensions. Bourgain proved that harmonic measure in any n space domain has dimension less than n. In work from 2005 - 2010, coauthors and myself obtained an endpoint type generalization of Makarov's theorem for p harmonic measure in a planar simply connected domain. We showed that if p is between 1 and 2 then p harmonic measure always has dimension at least 1 while if p is larger than 2 the dimension of p harmonic measure is at most 1. Coauthors and myself also generalized the three space paper of Wolff mentioned above, obtaining that the natural analogue in space of our planar results, was false for p in some small interval about two. During 2013 - 2018 (the time period for this NSF grant) we were able to prove that if p is larger than n, then in any n space domain, the dimension of p harmonic measure is at most n - 1. Also if the domain is simply connected we showed that n harmonic measure has dimension at most n - 1. Our work extended the results of Jones and Wolff to n space. Later we proved a similar result for a more general PDE of p Laplace type. This PDE had been studied earlier by my former PhD student, Murat Akman, who in his 2014 PhD thesis obtained for a more general measure than p harmonic measure, the same dimension estimates as for p harmonic measure in the simply connected planar case.

The study of p harmonic measure also led myself and coauthors to study related topics (for PDE's of p Laplace type) such as boundary Harnack inequalities, free boundary problems, Brunn - Minkowski inequalities, and Minkowski existence theorems for convex domains in n space. We proved theorems on these topics which previously had been reserved for Laplace's equation.

As for proofs, our work on p harmonic measure used heavily the fact that a solution to the p Laplacian (called p harmonic) and its derivatives both satisfy the same divergence form PDE (this fact turned out to be because the p Laplacian is homogeneous of degree p - 1). In the simply connected case discussed above, we then showed that the logarithm of the gradient of a p harmonic function is a super solution when p is between 1 and 2, and a subsolution to this PDE when p is greater than 2. Also in n space we obtained that the logarithm of the gradient of a p harmonic function is a subsolution to this PDE when p is at least n. Using these results we were able to make use of proof schemes for harmonic measure. Similar ideas were involved in other work.

Hopefully our work on the p Laplacian will eventually be used in mathematical modeling to explain some physical processes not covered by such linear PDE as the wave, heat or Laplace's equation.


Last Modified: 10/23/2018
Modified by: John L Lewis
